title: FirstFT: Musk victory triggers debate on Twitter's future
text:
A fierce debate about the future of Twitter has begun after Elon Musk pulled off a stunning victory to secure the support of the social media company's board for a $44bn takeover.

Among Democrats there was widespread alarm about the prospect of former president Donald Trump rejoining the platform while Republicans were jubilant.

Trump himself appeared to rule out a return to Twitter, telling Fox News yesterday that he would communicate via his own social media venture, Truth Social. Other Republicans, however, looked forward to their return to the platform.

Marjorie Taylor Greene, the controversial Republican member of Congress whose personal account was banned, said: “Prepare for blue check mark full scale meltdown after @elonmusk seals the deal and I should get my personal Twitter account restored.”

But Democrats said the platform's content moderation rules could be relaxed under Musk's ownership, leading to an explosion of hate speech and misinformation.

Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic senator from Massachusetts, who has publicly clashed with Musk on the platform, tweeted: “This deal is dangerous for our democracy. Billionaires like Elon Musk play by a different set of rules than everyone else, accumulating power for their own gain. We need a wealth tax and strong rules to hold Big Tech accountable.”

In a statement released to announce the deal, Musk said: “Free speech is the bedrock of a functioning democracy, and Twitter is the digital town square where matters vital to the future of humanity are debated.”

Musk, who will fund the $54.20 per share cash purchase from his vast personal wealth, has said he is not interested in the economic benefits of owning Twitter. Experts have warned looser content moderation policies will scare off advertisers.

Twitter yesterday raced to reassure advertising agencies in the wake of the deal announcement, telling them to expect business as usual and underlining its commitment to its existing product road map, according to screenshots of emails seen by the Financial Times. It will update investors on Thursday about the business when it releases earnings.

Investors, however, appeared to be warming to the deal. The shares, which have traded below the offer price since it was unveiled on April 14, rose 5.6 per cent in pre-market trading to $51.70.

Will Musk's ownership of Twitter make the platform better or worse? Send your thoughts to firstft@ft.com. Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas — Gordon

The latest from the war in Ukraine

  • Energy market: EU member states are looking at whether to impose a ceiling on what they would pay for Russian oil as a way to hit Kremlin revenues.

  • Business: Aircraft leasing companies have launched a multinational effort to persuade safety authorities to allow grounded planes that were returned from Russia without full maintenance records back into commercial service.

  • Moldova: Explosions struck the building housing the security services of the breakaway Moldovan republic of Transnistria, days after Moscow said the Russian-backed region could be drawn into the war in Ukraine.

  • Analysis: Stalling peace talks and a renewed Russian offensive suggest the Kremlin could escalate its “special operation” into a “war” against the west.

Five more stories in the news

1. Corporate America and investors square off over SEC proposal Corporate America and its largest investors are at odds over new regulations meant to “modernise” the way shareholders report their holdings.

2. European banks report mixed fortunes HSBC blamed increased reserves for bad loans because of the war in Ukraine and slowing growth in Asia for a fall in first-quarter profits. But underlying profits at Spanish bank Santander were buoyed by the recovery from coronavirus in Europe and UBS had its best first quarter since 2007.

3. Beijing to test millions for Covid City authorities announced that nearly 20mn residents would undergo three rounds of PCR tests from Tuesday to Saturday as China's capital tries to avoid the kind of mass outbreak seen in Shanghai.

4. Donald Trump found in contempt of court by New York judge Donald Trump has been found in contempt of court for failing to turn over documents to the New York attorney-general as she probes financial dealings by the former president and his business.

5. Turkish philanthropist jailed for life without parole An Istanbul court has sentenced Osman Kavala to life in jail without parole in a landmark case — a verdict campaigners described as an “outrageous” blow to rights.

The day ahead

US defence chief in Germany Lloyd Austin will host a meeting of Nato counterparts in Ramstein, Germany. Ahead of the meeting Germany reversed its position and said it would deliver “Gepard” armoured vehicles to Ukraine. UN secretary-general António Guterres continues diplomatic efforts to end the war with a trip to Moscow.

Company earnings Google owner Alphabet and Microsoft kick off Big Tech's first-quarter earnings season today. General Electric, 3M, PepsiCo, UPS and Warner Bros Discovery also report earnings.

Economic data The Census Bureau is expected to report that new orders of long-lasting goods jumped 1 per cent in March from a decline of 2.1 per cent in February, according to analysts polled by Refinitiv. Home prices in the Case-Shiller index's 20-city composite are expected to have climbed 19 per cent year on year in February, according to a Refinitiv poll of economists.

What else we're reading and watching

America's lopsided China strategy Washington may be immersed in the war in Ukraine, but the Biden administration is also focused on what it sees as its big long-term priority: developing a strategy to deal with Beijing. And after the turbulence of the Trump years, it is going out of its way to ensure the US and its partners are closely aligned.

The Netflix effect is here to stay We know the streaming service will survive — we just don't know how. In that respect, writes Stephen Bush, Netflix is like the Hoover: a once-dominant player that is guaranteed an eternal life as the codifying example. FT readers also joined the debate: “Netflix is a cheap money bubble stock which has had way too long of a run,” wrote Economatic.

US-China Tech Race: brave new world In this episode of the Tech Tonic podcast, James Kynge discusses how a mysterious death in Belgrade prompted Serbia to embrace Chinese surveillance technology, raising concerns among Serbian human rights and privacy activists.

Le Pen vows to stick around despite third failed presidential bid Marine Le Pen's concession speech suggested the far-right candidate is not ready to give up the mantle of opposition leader to newly re-elected French president Emmanuel Macron, who faces a complex economic juggling act.

  • Go deeper: Explore Macron's election victory over Le Pen in charts.

Food & drink

Andy Baraghani made his name as a YouTube chef. Dubbed “the internet boyfriend of our dreams” by Out magazine, he is back with the release next month of his debut cookbook, The Cook You Want to Be, and tastier than ever.
